channel.title: Superconductors on Archibald
channel.description: Recent content in Superconductors on Archibald

item.title: He Was Right About the Territory. The Map Is Still Being Drawn.
item.description: In 1968, Herbert Fröhlich published a paper in the International Journal of Quantum Chemistry proposing that biological macromolecules could exhibit long-range coherent quantum oscillations, driven by metabolic energy, analogous to Bose-Einstein condensation. The prediction was specific: above a critical threshold of energy input, a biological system driven far from thermal equilibrium would channel excess energy into a single quantum mode, producing collective oscillations in the terahertz range. He called it a condensate. The community eventually called it Fröhlich coherence.

item.title: NASA Spent Six Hundred Thousand Dollars and Never Ran the Test. The Inventor Won't Tell You Why.
item.description: In the early 1990s, a Russian materials scientist at Tampere University of Technology in Finland claimed that a rotating superconducting ceramic disk reduced the weight of objects placed above it by somewhere between 0.05 and 0.5 percent. His name was Evgeny Podkletnov. The claim was specific, the mechanism was unspecified, the effect was small enough that it might have been measurement error, and nobody in mainstream physics had a theoretical framework that would predict anything like it.
